prompts.prompt: How can you tell if a verb is first conjugation? What should you look for in the dictionary entry?

criteria: Explains that you look at the second principal part (infinitive)
May give an example (e.g., amō, amāre)
excellent.example_response: First conjugation verbs have infinitives ending in -āre. You look at the second principal part in the dictionary entry - like 'amō, amāre' - the 'amāre' ending tells you it's first conjugation.

criteria: May not mention it's the infinitive/second principal part
good.example_response: They end in -āre, like amāre means 'to love.'

criteria: May confuse with other conjugations or with noun declensions
developing.example_response: I think it has something to do with the -a- vowel?

insufficient.example_response: Is it about the noun endings?

follow_up_if_good: Excellent! So if I give you 'vocō, vocāre' - is this first conjugation?
Perfect! Can you name one or two first conjugation verbs we've learned?
follow_up_if_developing: Let's look at the verb 'amō, amāre, amāvī, amātum.' Which part tells you the conjugation?
Remember: the infinitive (the 'to [verb]' form) ends in -āre for first conjugation. Can you spot that in our vocabulary?

prompts.prompt: What are the personal endings for Latin verbs? Can you give me at least the singular forms?

criteria: Provides all six personal endings correctly: -ō/-m, -s, -t, -mus, -tis, -nt
May note that 1st sg. uses -ō in present but -m in imperfect/future
excellent.example_response: The personal endings are: -ō (or -m) for 'I,' -s for 'you,' -t for 'he/she/it,' -mus for 'we,' -tis for 'you all,' and -nt for 'they.' The 1st person singular uses -ō in present tense but -m in imperfect and future.

criteria: May have minor errors or omissions

follow_up_if_good: Great! Now, what's the difference between using -ō and using -m for first person singular?
Perfect! Can you conjugate 'amō' in the present tense using these endings?
follow_up_if_developing: Let's start with 'you' (singular). What's that ending?
Here's a hint: amō (I), amās (you), amat (he/she/it). Can you see the pattern?

prompts.prompt: What's the difference between 'amat' and 'amābat'? How do you know which tense each one is?

criteria: Identifies 'amat' as present tense (loves, is loving)
Identifies 'amābat' as imperfect tense (was loving, used to love)
Shows understanding of the time difference (present vs. ongoing/habitual past)
excellent.example_response: 'Amat' is present tense meaning 'he/she/it loves' or 'is loving.' 'Amābat' is imperfect tense meaning 'he/she/it was loving' or 'used to love.' You can tell because 'amābat' has the -bā- marker between the stem and the ending, which always signals imperfect tense.

criteria: May not fully explain the time/aspect difference
good.example_response: 'Amat' is present (loves) and 'amābat' is imperfect (was loving). The -ba- tells you it's imperfect.

criteria: May recognize -bā- but not explain it well
developing.example_response: I think 'amat' is present... and 'amābat' might be past?

follow_up_if_good: Excellent! So what would be the future tense of this same verb (3rd person singular)?
Perfect! Can you explain when you'd use imperfect vs. present in a sentence?
follow_up_if_developing: Let's look at the structure. Do you see any extra letters in 'amābat' that aren't in 'amat'?
The -bā- is the key. That always means imperfect (past, ongoing). Can you try again?

prompts.prompt: I'm going to give you a verb form: 'amābunt.' What tense is this, and how do you know?

criteria: Identifies as future tense, 3rd person plural
Explains the -bu- marker (variant of -bi-) signals future
May contrast with present 'amant' or imperfect 'amābant' to show understanding
excellent.example_response: 'Amābunt' is future tense, 3rd person plural - 'they will love.' I know because of the -bu- marker before the -nt ending. The -bu- is a variant of -bi- that's used with the -nt ending in future tense. It's different from 'amant' (present) which has no marker, and 'amābant' (imperfect) which has -bā-.

good.example_response: It's future tense - 'they will love.' The -bu- shows it's future.

criteria: Uncertain about tense (may guess future or imperfect)
developing.example_response: Is it imperfect? Or maybe future? I'm not sure...

follow_up_if_good: Excellent! This is tricky because -bu- only appears in 3rd plural future. What would be the 3rd singular future?
Perfect! Can you explain why it's -bu- and not -bi- in this form?
follow_up_if_developing: Let's compare: 'amant' (present), 'amābant' (imperfect), 'amābunt' (future). Do you see the different markers?
The -bu- appears in future tense with -nt. The -bā- appears in imperfect. Which one do you see here?

prompts.prompt: Why does first conjugation use -bi- for future tense instead of -bā- like imperfect? What's the logic behind having different tense markers?

criteria: Explains that different markers distinguish different tenses
May mention historical/linguistic reasons (if known) or simply explain functional purpose
excellent.example_response: Latin uses different tense markers to clearly distinguish tenses. The -bā- marker is reserved for imperfect tense (ongoing or habitual past action), while -bi-/-bu- marks future tense. This prevents confusion - if you see -ba-, you know it's imperfect; if you see -bi-/-bu-, you know it's future. These markers are consistent across all conjugations, which makes Latin verb morphology systematic and predictable. Historically, these come from different Indo-European roots, but functionally, they serve to keep the tenses distinct.

criteria: Recognizes that different markers distinguish tenses
good.example_response: The different markers help you tell the tenses apart. -Bā- is always imperfect and -bi- is always future, so you can't confuse them.

criteria: May recognize the distinction but not explain why
developing.example_response: I guess they're different so you know which is which?

insufficient.example_response: I have no idea. Maybe it's just random?

prompts.note: This is a higher-order question testing understanding of morphology and linguistic function, not just memorization.
follow_up_if_good: Excellent linguistic thinking! So if you encounter a new conjugation pattern (like 2nd or 3rd), would you expect to see the same -bā- and -bi-/-bu- markers?
Great answer! This systematic use of markers is one reason Latin is considered a 'regular' language compared to English. Can you think of how English forms its past tense inconsistently?
follow_up_if_developing: Think about it this way: if both imperfect and future used -bā-, how would you tell 'was loving' from 'will love'?
The markers create a system. Imperfect always has -bā-, future always has -bi-/-bu-. Why is that helpful when reading Latin?

prompts.prompt: Translate this sentence and explain your grammatical reasoning: 'Puellae aquam portābant.' What tense is the verb, and how do you know? What case is each noun and why?

criteria: Correct translation: 'The girls were carrying water' or 'The girls used to carry water'
Identifies 'portābant' as 3rd plural imperfect (because of -bā- marker)
Explains reasoning clearly for each grammatical decision
excellent.example_response: 'The girls were carrying water' or 'The girls used to carry water.' 'Portābant' is 3rd person plural imperfect - I know because of the -bā- tense marker and the -nt ending (they). It's imperfect, so it describes ongoing or habitual past action. 'Puellae' is nominative plural (the girls as subject - who was carrying). 'Aquam' is accusative singular (water as direct object - what was being carried).

criteria: Provides reasoning but may lack some detail
good.example_response: 'The girls were carrying water.' The verb is imperfect (has -ba-). Puellae is nominative plural (subject) and aquam is accusative (object).

criteria: May identify some elements correctly but miss others
Shows effort but gaps in understanding
developing.example_response: 'The girls carry water.' Puellae is nominative and aquam is accusative. The verb is... imperfect maybe?

insufficient.example_response: 'The girl will carry water?' I'm not sure about the cases.

prompts.note: This tests integrated understanding - recognizing verb tense, noun cases, and translating accurately.
follow_up_if_good: Excellent analysis! How would the sentence change if I wanted to say 'The girls will carry water' instead?
Perfect! What if I made aquam plural - 'aquās'? How would your translation change?
follow_up_if_developing: Let's break it down. First, look at 'portābant.' Do you see -bā-? What does that tell you?
For the nouns: 'puellae' - is this nominative plural or some other form? How do you know?

mastery_criteria.note: Student should demonstrate understanding across basic (identifying conjugation, personal endings), intermediate (tense recognition and comparison), and advanced (morphological reasoning, integrated sentence analysis) levels
